Comment: Ok, this is already very strange.
Ok, this is already very strange.
Ok, this is already very strange.
Ok, this is already very strange.
Just waiting for Qa5+, c3, b4, Qc2, etc., being a "naive" attack I can handle.
No pieces out for black at this point, and leaving the black squares so unprotected, is weird, but I cannot say I see how to take advantage from the weakness so promptly.
Wonderful, black underestimates the dangers of retarded piece developement.
Wonderful, black underestimates the dangers of retarded piece developement.
I still don't see the way to break in, so I played the nomal London attack (my way), assuring a square in g3 for the bishop, in case of g5, thinking in h4 etc., with nice tactics involved.
Black makes a threat of his position. I was careless, and it took me a little by surprise.
Black makes a threat of his position. I was careless, and it took me a little by surprise.
Black makes a threat of his position. I was careless, and it took me a little by surprise.
The knight has to wait for hxg4 before jumping at e5. And I was "punctured in my pride" (as we say in Italian ;-) and I had to demostrate that all was part of my plan. :-)
Black can save the pawn with f5, but I still think I'll have the better hand of it. but of course the h pawn "question" still needs an answer...
Black can save the pawn with f5, but I still think I'll have the better hand of it. but of course the h pawn "question" still needs an answer...
Black considers gxh4 ineffective, probably due to Qxg4 (which I intended to play, indeed). And this threatens e4, while prevents the queen to take g4. Not bad at all.
I play this knight here, to avoid pins if Bb4. Black can even think in an attack based on Bb4, c3, Ba4, followed by b4.
Normal. The knight will fly to g4 anyway, but then black will have e5.
Being a bit more developed should count something, so I open the game.
Being a bit more developed should count something, so I open the game.
Being a bit more developed should count something, so I open the game.
Now it had become very tactic all of a sudden.

Ok, now white should be able to take back the lost piece, but I had the poor guy making through a frightening variety of lines, very difficult to analyze on a blitz game. What would have been your choice? Black has to take material back (at least a pawn, but which and how?), he has to decide if he likes or not the queen's exchange...
...calculating that a queen in f6 couldn't be bad, pressing on the white's messy kingside pawns.
No more play: I have to take back it, no trick on sight.
b2 is threatened. But both black and I overlooked the stunning 14. hxg5!, but be aware: Qxg5, 15. RxR, Qxg3+, 16. Ke2... it seems safe for white.

I didn't see it, but still I considered safe to avoid more complications, and solve once for all the h4 question. I decided I wouldn't care for qxb2. It just will distract the black queen from the action, and I would have started with Nb3, threatening Bxd6.
Logic. The natural answer was f4, but I dared...
This was a mistake, but I thought that I would better have not trapped my queen. I didn't consider...
